items.title: Update HTML example in descendant combinator

items.content_html:
Summary

This wraps children of MathML <mtd> cells into an <mrow> group, except for the mtable and mtd articles:

find files/ -type f -name '*.md' | grep -v mtable/index.md | grep -v mtd/index.md | xargs sed -i 's|<mtd>|<mtd><mrow>|g;s|</mtd>|</mrow></mtd>|g'

Per the MathML specifications, there should be no rendering change. However Firefox does perform line breaking inside MathML table cells when the explicit <mrow> is absent (and does not otherwise). Note that this change is really only useful when the <mtd> element contains at least two children, but it's easier to write a command line if the remaining cases are included too.

Motivation

Users reported broken rendering in Firefox on twitter. Adding an explicit <mrow> prevents undesired line breaking inside MathML table cells.

Supporting details

twitter thread where the issue was reported
fix for the missing parentheses

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Wrap children of <mtd> elements into an <mrow> to prevent line breaking.

items.content_html:
This PR updates the Serial API for new-style event pages. (see the template)

Commands used:

yarn content move Web/API/SerialPort/onconnect Web/API/SerialPort/connect_event
yarn content move Web/API/SerialPort/ondisconnect Web/API/SerialPort/disconnect_event
yarn content delete Web/API/Serial/onconnect --redirect=/en-US/docs/Web/API/SerialPort/connect_event 
yarn content delete Web/API/Serial/ondisconnect --redirect=/en-US/docs/Web/API/SerialPort/disconnect_event

As discussed in mdn/browser-compat-data#13925, SerialPort bubbles to Serial and so I documented these two events only under SerialPort and the Serial page just contains them as links but not as sub pages to avoid duplication.
items.title: Update Serial API for new-style event pages

items.content_html:
Summary

Fix the polyfill of Math.fround that does not rely on Float32Array.

Motivation

As shown here:
https://gist.github.com/shicks/7a97ec6b3f10212e60a89a7f6d2d097d?permalink_comment_id=4048135#gistcomment-4048135
the old polyfill was incorrect, because it was breaking ties upwards when rounding. The spec of fround requires to break ties to even instead.

The new polyfill correctly breaks ties to even, even at the critical points of transitioning from subnormal to normal forms, and from finite to infinity.

To perform ties-to-even, the code relies on the natural rounding that will happen when getting into the subnormal forms of (64-bit) numbers.

In addition, the new polyfill does not assume that Math.log will always return the best approximation. The spec of Math.log explicitly says that it may not return the best approximation.

Supporting details

  • The gist with the old polyfill, with the test cases that break, and the new implementation: https://gist.github.com/shicks/7a97ec6b3f10212e60a89a7f6d2d097d?permalink_comment_id=4048135#gistcomment-4048135
  • The new polyfill is the one used by Scala.js. In the Scala.js codebase, it is written as a JS AST here. Its tests are here

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Fix the polyfill of Math.fround.

items.content_html:
This is an experiment at a more through rewrite of the JS Learn async module.

I have a PR open to make some incremental changes to the JS async docs: #12440.

But the more I look at these docs the more I wonder if we could do much better at explaining it. So I spent a bit of time working on a couple of articles that might replace some of the existing docs.

The existing module has:

  1. General asynchronous programming concepts
  2. Introducing asynchronous JavaScript
  3. Cooperative asynchronous JavaScript: Timeouts and intervals
  4. Handling async operations gracefully with Promises
  5. Making asynchronous programming easier with async and await
  6. Choosing the right approach

I feel like 3 doesn't really belong here, as I said in #12461. I also think 6 is a really strange article.

And I think a lot of the rest is quite repetitive and long-winded, and has lots of sort of half-explanations of things. Like for instance: General asynchronous programming concepts starts by talking about sync functions, then has a sort of half-hearted discussion of threading, then introduces workers, then goes into async, with some comments I don't understand about "although code run in a worker is not blocking, it is still basically synchronous". I don't really understand the point of this.

Then in the next article (Introducing asynchronous JavaScript), we start by talking about blocking sync functions again - why? And so on.

I was also motivated by a couple of issues: #10464 and #10442 - I know these issues are not exactly specific, but I must say I tend to agree with them.

So. I spent a bit of time writing a couple of articles, which I pushed to this draft PR:

  • https://pr12525.content.dev.mdn.mozit.cloud/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Asynchronous/Introducing : this replaces basically 1 and 2, explaining the motivation for async, and going a bit into the old ways JS supported async.
  • https://pr12525.content.dev.mdn.mozit.cloud/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Asynchronous/Promises : this replaces 4 and 5 (mostly), and talks about how to use promise-based APIs

They are a little rough still but good enough to ask for feedback. I would expect to have a quite short third article talking about implementing a Promise-based API (but keep this brief as it's not such a common thing to need to do, especially for beginners). And I think it might be worth having a fourth article on workers.

Anyway. I'm interested to know things like:

  • do we think this is better? Clearer?
  • am I losing a lot of important detail?
  • should I continue with this or just stick to the incremental updates?
items.title: First draft of some new async articles

items.content_html:
This PR updates the Sensor API for new-style event pages.

  • Ran yarn content move Web/API/Sensor/onerror Web/API/Sensor/error_event

  • Ran yarn content move Web/API/Sensor/onreading Web/API/Sensor/reading_event

  • Ran yarn content move Web/API/Sensor/onactivate Web/API/Sensor/activate_event

  • Updated https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Sensor:

    • Moved the "Event handlers" section to an "Events" section
    • Linked to xxx_event pages instead of onxxx
    • Sort events alphabetically. Update descriptions

  • Updated Web/API/Sensor/activate_event (moved in the first step)

    • Updated to new-style event page. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/MDN/Structures/Page_types/API_event_subpage_template for the template.
    • Added example code.

  • Updated Web/API/Sensor/error_event (same update as activate event, but note this is of type SensorErrorEvent)

  • Updated Web/API/Sensor/reading_event (same update as activate event)

  • Searched all of mdn/content for "sensor.on" to update any pages that reference sensor "on" event handlers and updated them. Did some adjacent changes like adding inheritance diagrams and fixing syntax boxes.

BCD change is approved in mdn/browser-compat-data#13926
items.title: Update Sensor API for new-style event pages

items.content_html:
I don’t know how to include the sample result, nor how to update the compatibility table. According to https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/semantics-other.html#selector-invalid the fieldset:invalid is part of the spec. https://caniuse.com/?search=%3Ainvalid doesn’t mention fieldset specifically, but does include form:invalid; IE is, of course, out, while curent Edge is in (older Edge was out).

Motivation

items.content_html:
Summary

This is a complete overhaul of the window.open() page and accomplishes the following:

  • Cuts down on the verbosity of the page.
  • Reorganizes the page to fit the API method subpage template.
  • Removes misleading or outdated information.
  • Clarifies the code examples

Things that should be considered:

  • There was an edit to this page in response to #11988 that I left out because I think the issue is better answered now with the rework, but to each their own!
  • This is my first contribution to MDN, so feedback is appreciated. This should be considered a first draft.

Hopefully I did this right!

Motivation

There is an open issue to overhaul this page. See below.

Supporting details

Related issues

Fixes #4583
